revision.text:
[[File:Blackie and Churchill (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|280px|[[Winston Churchill]] restrains Blackie, the ship's cat of [[HMS Prince of Wales (53)|HMS ''Prince of Wales'']], from boarding {{USS|McDougal|DD-358|6}} during a 1941 ceremonial visit|alt=Atlantic Conference August 1941: Churchill restrains 'Blackie' the cat, the mascot of HMS ''Prince of Wales'', from joining the USS ''McDougal'', an American destroyer, while the ship's company stand to attention during the playing of the National Anthem]] [[File:A cat on HMAS Encounter.jpg|thumb|Ship's cat on {{HMAS|Encounter|1902|6}} during [[World War I]] ]] [[File:Captain A. J. Hailey in uniform with a cat on the first C.P. R.M.S. Empress of Canada.jpg|thumb|upright|Captain A. J. Hailey with his cat on the {{RMS|Empress of Canada|1922}}, 1920s|upright]]
The '''ship's cat''' has been a common feature on many [[Merchant vessel|trading]], [[History of research ships|exploration]], and [[naval ship]]s dating to [[ancient times]]. Cats have been carried on ships for many reasons, most importantly to control rodents. [[Vermin]] aboard a ship can cause damage to ropes, woodwork, and more recently, electrical wiring. Also, rodents threaten ships' stores, devour crews' foodstuff, and could cause economic damage to ships' cargo such as grain. They are also a [[Vector (epidemiology)|source of disease]], which is dangerous for ships that are at sea for long periods of time. [[Oriental rat flea|Rat flea]]s are carriers of [[Plague (disease)|plague]], and rats on ships were believed to be a main spreader of the [[Black Death]].
Cats naturally attack and kill rodents,<ref name="bruzelius">{{Cite web | last = Bruzelius | first = Lars | title = Sailing Ships | work = Stevens: ‘Vermin’, 1894 | publisher = The Maritime History Virtual Archives | year = 2005 | url = http://www.bruzelius.info/Nautica/Seamanship/Stevens%281894%29_S1156.html | accessdate = April 20, 2010}}</ref> and their natural ability to adapt to new surroundings made them suitable for service on a ship. In addition, they offer companionship and a sense of home, security and camaraderie to sailors away from home.
== History ==
The domestication of cats is believed to date back to around 9,000 years ago on farms in the [[Near East]]. The Ancient Egyptians took cats on board [[Nile boat]]s to catch birds in the [[thicket]]s along the riverbanks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paintings from the Tomb-chapel of Nebamun|url=https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/ancient-art-civilizations/egypt-art/new-kingdom/a/paintings-from-the-tomb-chapel-of-nebamun|website=Khan Academy|accessdate=25 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | contribution-url = http://www.purr-n-fur.org.uk/famous/simon.html | contribution = Simon of HMS Amethyst | title = Purr’n’fur | place = UK}}.</ref> A 2017 [[mitochondrial DNA]] study suggests that cats spread from [[ancient Egypt]] along maritime trade routes a few thousand years after first being domesticated.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Briggs|first1=Helen|title=How cats conquered the ancient world|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-40306897|accessdate=19 June 2017|work=BBC News|date=19 June 2017}}</ref> Preliminary results of a genetic study published in September 2016 concluded that cats were carried on trading ships to control rodents, and that practice was adopted by traders from many nations, including [[Vikings]] in northern Germany around the [[8th century|8th]] to [[11th century|11th]] centuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cats sailed with Vikings to conquer the world, genetic study reveals|url=http://www.sciencealert.com/cats-sailed-with-vikings-to-conquer-the-world-genetic-study-reveals|website=www.sciencealert.com|date=23 September 2016|publisher=Science Alert|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> The [[Norwegian Forest cat]] is a [[natural breed]] believed to have been developed from Viking ships' cats. [[Sailing ship]]s spread the domestic cat throughout much of the rest of the world during the [[Age of Discovery]] in the [[15th century|15th]] through [[18th century|18th]] centuries.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Mason|editor1-first=Ian L.|title=Evolution of domesticated animals|date=1984|publisher=Longman|location=London|isbn=0-582-46046-8|page=223}}</ref>
== Cats and superstition == Sometimes [[Cats in ancient Egypt|worshipped as deities]], cats have long had a reputation as [[Magic (paranormal)|magical]] animals and numerous [[myth]]s and [[superstition]]s sprang up among the unusually superstitious seafaring community.<ref>Eyers, Jonathan (2011). ''Don't Shoot the Albatross!: Nautical Myths and Superstitions''. A&C Black, London, UK. {{ISBN|978-1-4081-3131-2}}.</ref> They were considered to be intelligent and lucky animals, and a high level of care was devoted to keeping them happy. Some sailors believed that [[polydactyl cat]]s were better at catching pests, possibly connected with the suggestion that extra digits give a polydactyl cat better balance, important when at sea.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Moss |first1=Laura |title=11 things you didn't know about polydactyl cats |url=https://www.mnn.com/family/pets/stories/11-thing-didnt-know-polydactyl-cats |website=MNN |publisher=Mother Nature Network |quote= [Polydactyl cat's] large feet were thought to make them superior mousers, as well as provide better balance on the high seas. |language=en |date=September 16, 2015}}</ref> In some places polydactyl cats became known as "ship's cats".
Cats were believed to have miraculous powers that could protect ships from dangerous weather. Sometimes, fishermen's wives would keep [[black cat]]s at home too, in the hope that they would be able to use their influence to protect their husbands at sea. It was believed to be lucky if a cat approached a sailor on deck, but unlucky if it only came halfway, and then retreated. Another popular belief was that cats could start storms through magic stored in their tails. If a ship's cat fell or was thrown overboard, it was thought that it would summon a terrible storm to sink the ship and that if the ship was able to survive, it would be cursed with nine years of bad luck. Other beliefs included, if a cat licked its fur against the grain, it meant a [[hail]] [[storm]] was coming; if it sneezed it meant rain; and if it was frisky it meant wind.
Some of these beliefs are rooted in reality. Cats are able to detect slight changes in the weather, as a result of their very sensitive inner ears, which also allow them to land upright when falling. Low [[atmospheric pressure]], a common precursor of stormy weather, often makes cats nervous and restless.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Freeman|first1=Margot|title=How Do Cats React to Barometric Pressure?|url=http://pets.thenest.com/cats-react-barometric-pressure-12401.html|website=The Nest|publisher=XO Group Inc.|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> {{clear|left}}
== Notable examples == The prevalence of cats on ships has led to them being reported on by a number of noted seafarers. The outbreak of the [[Second World War]], with the spread of mass communication and the active nature of the world's navies, also led to a number of ship's cats becoming celebrities in their own right.<ref name="Famous ships cats and their lives">{{Citation | url = http://www.purr-n-fur.org.uk/featuring/war02.html | title = Famous ships cats and their lives | publisher = Purr’n’fur | place = United Kingdom}}.</ref>
=== Blackie === Blackie was [[HMS Prince of Wales (53)|HMS ''Prince of Wales'']]'s ship's cat. During the Second World War, he achieved worldwide fame after ''Prince of Wales'' carried [[Prime Minister]] [[Winston Churchill]] across the Atlantic to [[Naval Station Argentia|NS Argentia]], [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], in August 1941, where he secretly met with the [[United States President]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] for several days in a secure anchorage. This meeting resulted in the declaration of the [[Atlantic Charter]], but as Churchill prepared to step off ''Prince of Wales'', Blackie approached. Churchill stooped to bid farewell to Blackie, and the moment was photographed and reported in the world media. In honour of the success of the visit, Blackie was renamed Churchill.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.rjerrard.co.uk/royalnavy/rnbooks/rncats.htm | title = Royal Navy | contribution = Cats | publisher = R Jerrard | place = UK | type = book}}.</ref> Blackie survived the [[Sinking of Prince of Wales and Repulse|sinking of ''Prince of Wales'']] by the [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] later that year, and was taken to [[Singapore]] with the survivors. He could not be found when Singapore was evacuated the following year and his fate is unknown.<ref>{{cite web|title=Churchill’s Feline Menagerie|author1=Fred Glueckstein|url=http://www.winstonchurchill.org/support/the-churchill-centre/publications/finest-hour/issues-109-to-144/no-139/837-churchills-feline-menagerie|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429121822/http://www.winstonchurchill.org/support/the-churchill-centre/publications/finest-hour/issues-109-to-144/no-139/837-churchills-feline-menagerie|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 April 2010|publisher=The Churchill Centre|accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref>
=== Camouflage === Camouflage was the ship's cat aboard a US Coast Guard [[Landing Ship, Tank|LST]] in the Pacific theater, WWII. He was known for chasing enemy [[Tracer ammunition|tracer rounds]] across the deck.<ref name="USCG mascots">{{Citation | contribution-url = http://www.uscg.mil/history/uscghist/Mascots_2.asp | place = US | publisher = Coast Guard | title = History | contribution = Mascots}}.{{Dead link|date=July 2018|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref>
=== Chibley === Chibley was the ship's cat aboard the [[tall ship]] [[Barque]] [[Picton Castle (ship)|''Picton Castle'']]. She was rescued from an animal shelter and [[circumnavigated]] the world five times. ''Picton Castle''’s role as a training ship resulted in Chibley being introduced to a large number of visitors and becoming a celebrity in her own right. Chibley died on November 10, 2011, in Lunenburg, Nova Scotia. She had sailed over 180,000 miles at sea.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Captain Daniel Moreland|title=Captain's Log|url=http://www.picton-castle.com/captains_log/category/chibley/|website=www.picton-castle.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|location=Archive for the 'Chibley' Category|language=en|date=11 November 2011}}</ref>
=== Convoy === [[File:Convoy cat.jpg|thumb|right|Convoy asleep in a hammock aboard HMS ''Hermione'']] Convoy was the ship's cat aboard [[HMS Hermione (74)|HMS ''Hermione'']]. He was so named because of the number of times he accompanied the ship on [[Escort Group|convoy escort]] duties. Convoy was listed in the ship's book and provided with a full kit, including a tiny [[hammock]] in which he slept. He was killed along with 87 of his crew mates when ''Hermione'' was torpedoed and sunk on 16 June 1942 by [[German submarine U-205]].
=== Emmy === Emmy was the ship's cat on {{RMS|Empress of Ireland}}. She was an orange tabby cat who never missed a voyage. However, on 28 May 1914, Emmy jumped ship while in port in Quebec City. The crew returned her to the ship, but she left again, leaving her kittens behind. The ''Empress of Ireland'' left without her, which was regarded as a terrible omen.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blatchford|first1=Andy|title=Empress of Ireland, ‘Canada’s Titanic,’ finally getting its due after 100 years|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/empress-of-ireland-canadas-titanic-finally-getting-its-due-after-100-years/article18819164/?page=all|accessdate=7 January 2015|work=The Globe and Mail|publisher=The Canadian Press|date=23 May 2014}}</ref> Early the next morning ''Empress of Ireland'' collided with {{SS|Storstad}} while steaming through fog at the mouth of the St. Lawrence River and rapidly sank, killing over 1,000 people.
=== Felix === Felix was the ship's cat aboard ''[[Mayflower II]]'' when she set sail from Devon, England, to Plymouth, Massachusetts, in 1957 to symbolize the solidarity between the UK and the US following World War II. He was given his own life jacket and once suffered a broken paw after a mishap. The paw was set by the ship's doctor. Photos and stories about Felix appeared in ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'', ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', and ''[[Yankee (magazine)|Yankee]]'' magazine after his arrival in the US. The cat and the rest of the crew marched in a New York ticker tape parade and toured the East Coast that summer. He was eventually adopted by the cabin boy's girlfriend, Ann Berry, and settled in Waltham, Massachusetts. The current captain of the ''Mayflower II'' wrote a children's book about Felix entitled ''Felix and his Mayflower II Adventures''.<ref>{{isbn|9780979334818}}</ref> The book was published during the celebration of the ship's fiftieth anniversary at [[Plimoth Plantation]].<ref>{{Citation | contribution-url = http://www.plimoth.org/features/mayflower-2/journey/felix.php | title = The Journey of the Mayflower II | contribution = Felix | publisher = Plimoth}}.</ref>
=== Halifax === Halifax was the name given to Alvah and Diana Simon's ship's cat who was found in the port of Halifax, on their way to winter at Tay Bay in 1994, on ''Roger Henry''. The cat spent all of the time iced in on the boat with Alvah, when Diana had to leave for family purposes. Alvah's book ''North To The Night''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Simon|first1=Alvah|title=North to the Night: A Year in the Arctic Ice|date=1998|publisher=McGraw-Hill [u.a.]|location=Camden, ME |isbn=0-07-058052-9}}</ref> describes his adventure in the ice with Halifax the cat, who ended up losing half an ear to frostbite.
=== Jenny === Jenny was the name of the ship's cat aboard {{RMS|Titanic|3=2}} and was mentioned in the accounts of several of the crew members who survived the ocean liner's [[Sinking of the RMS Titanic|fateful 1912 maiden voyage]]. She was transferred from ''Titanic''{{'}}s sister ship {{RMS|Olympic|3=2}} and gave birth in the week before ''Titanic'' left Southampton. The galley is where Jenny and her kittens normally lived, cared for by the [[victualling]] staff who fed them kitchen scraps.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Eaton|first1=John P.|last2=Haas|first2=Charles A. |others= foreword by William MacQuitty|title=Titanic: A Journey Through Time|date=1999|publisher=Patrick Stephens|location=Sparkford|isbn=1-85260-575-8|page=234}}</ref> Stewardess [[Violet Jessop]] later wrote in her memoir that the cat "laid her family near Jim, the [[wikt:scullion|scullion]], whose approval she always sought and who always gave her warm devotion."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pellegrino|first1=Charles|authorlink=Charles R. Pellegrino|title=Farewell, Titanic : her final legacy|date=2012|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, N.J.|isbn=0-470-87387-6|page=29}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Titanic survivor : the newly discovered memoirs of Violet Jessop who survived both the Titanic and Britannic disasters|author=Violet Jessop|editor=John Maxtone-Graham|others= John Maxtone-Graham (annotated) |date=2004|publisher=Sheridan House|location=Dobbs-Ferry, NY|isbn=1-57409-184-0|edition=1st pbk.}}</ref>
Jenny and her kittens went down with the ship.
=== Kiddo === [[File:M. Vaniman and cat.jpg|thumb|left|upright|M. Vaniman and Kiddo]] Kiddo seemed to have stowed away on the [[airship]] [[America (airship)|''America'']], when she left from [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]], in an attempt to cross the [[Atlantic Ocean]] in 1910. Kiddo was upset at first by the experience, but settled in and evidently, was better at predicting bad weather than the [[barometer]]. The airship's engines failed, and the small crew and Kiddo abandoned the ''America'' for [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboats]] when they sighted the [[Royal Mail Ship|Royal Mail steamship]] ''[[SS Trent|Trent]]'', near [[Bermuda]]. Kiddo then was retired from being a ship's cat and was taken care of by Edith Wellman Ainsworth, the daughter of the American [[journalist]], [[explorer]], and [[aviator]], [[Walter Wellman]], who made the daring attempt.<ref>{{cite book | last = Janus | first = Allan | title = Animals Aloft: Photographs from the Smithsonian National Air & Space Museum | publisher = Bunker Hill Publishing | date = October 15, 2005 | isbn = 1-59373-048-9}}, 128 pp.</ref>
=== Mrs Chippy === {{Main|Mrs Chippy}} [[File:Mrschippy.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Mrs Chippy]], a tiger-striped male [[tabby]] ship's cat]] Mrs Chippy (actually a male) was the ship's cat aboard [[Endurance (1912 ship)|''Endurance'']], the ship used by Sir [[Ernest Shackleton]] for his [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]]. When the ship was lost, having become trapped and eventually crushed in pack ice, Shackleton ordered the sled dogs and Mrs Chippy shot, as Shackleton had decided that the animals could not be kept during the arduous journey ahead.
=== Nansen === Nansen was the ship's cat on {{ship|RV|Belgica|1884|2}}, which was used for the [[Belgian Antarctic Expedition]]. He was brought on board by cabin boy Johan Koren, and was named after [[Fridtjof Nansen]]. He died on 22 June 1898,<ref name = Lewis>{{cite book |title=Ship's Cats in War and Peace |last=Lewis |first=Val |year=2002 |publisher= Nauticalia | location =Shepperton |isbn=0-9530458-1-1|pages=59–60}}</ref> and was buried in the [[Antarctic]].<ref name=Cool>{{citation | url = http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/History/antarctic_whos_who_belgica.htm | first = Adrien | last = de Gerlache | title = Belgica Belgian Antarctic Expedition 1897–1899 | publisher = Cool Antarctica | accessdate = 5 October 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101009092129/http://coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/History/antarctic_whos_who_belgica.htm | archivedate = 9 October 2010 | df = }}</ref>
=== Peebles === [[File:Peebles the cat.jpg|thumb|left|Lieutenant Commander R H Palmer [[OBE]], [[Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve|RNVR]] plays with Peebles, the ship's cat, who leaps through his clasped arms on board HMS ''Western Isles'' at [[Tobermory, Mull]]]] Peebles was the ship's cat aboard [[HMS Western Isles|HMS ''Western Isles'']]. Another cat who became a favourite of the ship's crew, he was known to be particularly intelligent and would shake the hands of strangers when they entered the [[wardroom]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
=== Pooli === [[File:Pooli (cat).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Pooli in uniform on July 4, 1959, her 15th birthday]] Pooli served aboard a United States [[attack transport]] during the Second World War. <ref>{{Citation | url = http://digital2.library.ucla.edu/viewItem.do?ark=21198/zz0002qbjp | title = Changing Times: Los Angeles in Photographs, 1920–1990 (Pooli, cat who served aboard an United States attack transport during World War II celebrates 15th birthday) | type = photograph | newspaper = The Los Angeles Times | date = July 4, 1959 | publisher = UCLA }}.</ref> She was awarded with three [[service ribbon]]s and four [[battle star]]s.<ref name="USNI">{{cite web|title=Cats in the Sea Services|url=https://www.usni.org/news-and-features/cats-and-the-sea-services|website=www.usni.org|publisher=U.S. Naval Institute}}</ref>
=== Rinda === Rinda was the ship's cat on the Norwegian cargo ship {{SS|Rinda}}, which was torpedoed and sunk during World War II. When the surviving crew realized that their beloved ship's cat was not on board the lifeboat, they rowed around in the night until they finally heard a pitiful "miauu" in the distance. "We rowed as hard as we could and laughed and cried when we lifted the sopping wet furball aboard". The cat became the ship's cat aboard the rescue ship, the [[Trawlers of the Royal Navy|British armed naval trawler]] {{HMT|Pict|FY132|6}}, and was given the name Rinda after the previous ship.<ref name=Rinda>{{cite web |url = http://www.warsailors.com/singleships/rinda.html |title=D/S Rinda |publisher=War sailors |accessdate=7 February 2012}}</ref>
=== Simon === {{Main|Simon (cat)}}
Simon was the ship's cat of [[HMS Amethyst (F116)|HMS ''Amethyst'']] during the [[Yangtze Incident]] in 1949, and was wounded in the bombardment of the ship which killed 25 of ''Amethyst''’s crew, including the commanding officer. He soon recovered and resumed killing rats and keeping up the crew's morale. He was appointed to the rank of 'Able Seacat' Simon and became a [[celebrity]] after the ship escaped the Yangtze and returned to Britain. He later succumbed to an infection and died shortly after. Tributes poured in and his [[obituary]] appeared in ''[[The Times]]''. He was posthumously awarded the [[Dickin Medal]], the only cat ever to earn the award, and was buried with full naval honours.
=== Tarawa === Tarawa was a kitten rescued from a [[Pillbox (military)|pillbox]] during the [[Battle of Tarawa]] by the [[United States Coast Guard]]. She was a mascot aboard an [[Landing Ship, Tank|LST]], but did not get along with the LST's other mascot, a dog named Kodiak, and jumped ship ashore.<ref name="USCG mascots" />
=== Tiddles === [[File:Tiddles cat.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Tiddles at his station aboard HMS ''Victorious''. Despite a long tradition, there are no longer ships' cats aboard Royal Navy vessels]] Tiddles was the ship's cat on a number of [[Royal Navy]] [[aircraft carrier]]s. He was born aboard {{HMS |Argus|I49|6}}, and later joined {{HMS|Victorious|R38|6}}. He was often seen at his favourite station, on the aft [[capstan (nautical)|capstan]], where he would play with the bell-rope. He eventually travelled over {{convert |30000|mi|km}} during his time in service.
=== Trim === {{Main|Trim (cat)}} Trim was the ship's cat on a number of the ships under the command of [[Matthew Flinders]] during voyages to circumnavigate and map the coastline of Australia during 1801–1803. He became a favourite of the crew and was the first cat to circumnavigate Australia. He remained with Flinders until death. He has been the subject of a number of works of literature, and statues have been placed in his honour, including one that sits on a window sill at the [[State Library of New South Wales]] in Sydney.
=== Unsinkable Sam === {{Main|Unsinkable Sam}} Previously named Oscar, he was the ship's cat of the [[German battleship Bismarck|German battleship ''Bismarck'']]. When she was sunk on 27 May 1941, only 116 out of a crew of over 2,200 survived. Oscar was picked up by the destroyer [[HMS Cossack (F03)|HMS ''Cossack'']] (one of the ships responsible for destroying ''Bismarck''). ''Cossack'' herself was torpedoed and sunk a few months later, on 24 October, killing 159 of her crew, but Oscar again survived to be rescued, and was taken to [[Gibraltar]]. He became the ship's cat of [[HMS Ark Royal (91)|HMS ''Ark Royal'']], which was torpedoed and sunk in November that year. Oscar was again rescued, but it was decided at that time to transfer him to a home on land. By now known as Unsinkable Sam because of surviving the three ship sinkings, he was given a new job as mouse-catcher in the Governor General's of Gibraltar office buildings. He eventually returned to the UK and spent the rest of his life at the 'Home for Sailors'. A portrait of him exists in the private collection of the [[National Maritime Museum]] in [[Greenwich]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Baker|first1=Georgina Shaw|title=Item #PAJ2744: ''Oscar, Cat From the German Battleship Bismarck'' - Private Collections of the National Maritime Museum|url=http://collections.rmg.co.uk/collections/objects/203480.html|website=Royal Museums Greenwich|location=London, UK|format=Framed drawing in pastel, 785 x 610 mm}}</ref>
== Today ==
The [[Royal Navy]] banned cats and other pet animals from all ships on the ocean in 1975 on [[hygiene]] grounds;<ref name="Famous ships cats and their lives" /> however, cats are still common on many private ships.
One notable example is ''Toolbox'' (a feral kitten born in a toolbox), the senior ship's cat, official warrant officer and "Captain's Assistant" aboard [[Kalmar Nyckel#The modern Kalmar Nyckel|the modern ''Kalmar Nyckel'']]. A celebrity in her own right, she is the subject of two books.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mayers|first1=Barbara|title=Toolbox: Ship's Cat on the Kalmar Nyckel|date=2007|publisher=Bay Oak Publishers, Limited|isbn=9780974171395|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Toolbox.html?id=q3LvHwAACAAJ&redir_esc=y|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Charles E. Ireland, Jr.|title=Toolbox|date=2006|publisher=Cedar Tree Books|url=http://cedartreebooks.com/catalog/1-books/29-toolbox|language=en-us}}</ref> Also, American sailor [[Robin Lee Graham]] was the youngest solo sailor to circumnavigate the globe, beginning in 1965. A number of ship's cats were included in the chronicles for the ''[[National Geographic Magazine]]'' (1968–1970) and detailed in the 1972 book ''Dove'', which was adapted into the 1974 film ''[[The Dove (1974 film)|The Dove]]''.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
== In fiction == There are at least two books called ''The Ship's Cat'': [[The Ship's Cat|a 1977 children's book]] by [[Richard Adams]] and [[Alan Aldridge]],<ref>{{ISBN|978-0-224-01441-0}}</ref> and a 2000 novel by [[Jock Brandis]].<ref>{{ISBN|978-0595129973}}</ref> ''[[Matthew Flinders' Cat]]'' is a 2002 novel by [[Bryce Courtenay]] featuring tales about [[Trim (cat)|Trim]], the ship's cat that circumnavigated Australia. In ''Fish Head'', a 1954 children's book by [[Jean Fritz]], the eponymous cat unwittingly becomes a ship's cat.<ref>{{Citation | last = Fritz | first = Jean | title = Fish head | url = https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/jean-fritz/fish-head/ | journal = Kirkus Reviews}}.</ref>
In a central episode in [[Jan de Hartog]]'s novel ''[[The Captain (1967 novel)|The Captain]]'', taking place on board a ship engaged in the dangerous [[Murmansk Convoy]]s in the [[Second World War]], a young officer is killed in an effort to save the ship's cat and her playful kittens during a [[Luftwaffe]] attack on the ship. This profoundly affects the main protagonist, the ship's captain, and is one of the factors leading to his later becoming a [[conscientious objector]].
In [[science fiction]], the role of the ship's cat has been transferred to spaceships. Notable examples include [[Cordwainer Smith]]'s 1955 short story "[[The Game of Rat and Dragon]]"<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.gutenberg.org/files/29614/29614-h/29614-h.htm | last = Smith | first = Cordwainer | title = The game of Rat and Dragon | journal = Galaxy Science Fiction |date=October 1955 | publisher = Project Gutenberg}}</ref> and [[Andre Norton]]'s 1968 novel ''The Zero Stone''<ref>{{cite web|title=THE ZERO STONE by Andre Norton|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/andre-norton/the-zero-stone/|website=[[Kirkus Reviews]]|publisher=Kirkus Media|accessdate=19 April 2018|language=en-us}}</ref> featuring a telepathic mutant feline named Eet.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Zero Stone (#1)|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1183868.The_Zero_Stone|website=www.goodreads.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> On film, ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]'' (1979) and the sequel ''[[Aliens (film)|Aliens]]'' (1989) feature Jones ("Jonesy") aboard USCSS ''Nostromo''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burton|first1=Bonnie|authorlink1=Bonnie Burton|title=Ripley and her cat make 'Aliens' look cuddly|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/ripley-cat-jonesy-aliens-alien-sci-fi-movie-sigourney-weaver/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=19 April 2018|language=en|date=8 December 2016}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Cats|Nautical}} * [[List of cats]] {{clear}}

H. C.|title=Signal Service Notes: Weather Proverbs|date=1883|publisher=Office of the Chief Signal Office|location=Washington|pages=29–30|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ucolAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA29&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q&f=false|language=en|chapter=Proverbs relating to animals}} — Collection of proverbs relating to cats predicting weather

{{Infobox album | name = Surrender | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Sarah Brightman]] &
[[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] | cover = Surrender-SarahBrightman.jpg | alt = | released = 1995 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Musicals, Show Tunes | length = 68:39 | label = | producer = | prev_title = [[Sarah Brightman Sings the Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber]] | prev_year = 1992 | next_title = [[The Andrew Lloyd Webber Collection]] | next_year = 1997 }} '''''Surrender''''' is an album by [[England|English]] [[soprano]] [[Sarah Brightman]] featuring songs composed by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]. The album’s booklet also includes Lloyd Webber's commentary for each song. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | total_length = 68:39 | title1 = Surrender | music1 = from ''[[Sunset Boulevard (musical)|Sunset Boulevard]]'' | length1 = 3:06 | title2 = [[Unexpected Song]] | music2 = from ''[[Song and Dance]]'' | length2 = 2:56 | title3 = Chanson d'Enfance | music3 = from ''[[Aspects of Love]]'' | length3 = 3:55 | title4 = [[Tell Me on a Sunday]] | music4 = from ''[[Tell Me on a Sunday]]''/''[[Song and Dance]]'' | length4 = 3:45 | title5 = Nothing Like You've Ever Known | music5 = from ''[[Tell Me on a Sunday]]/[[Song and Dance]]'' | length5 = 3:09 | title6 = Macavity: The Mystery Cat | music6 = from ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'' | length6 = 4:44 | title7 = [[Gus: The Theatre Cat]] | note7 = feat. [[John Gielgud|Sir John Gielgud]] | music7 = from ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'' | length7 = 5:11 | title8 = Piano | note8 = “[[Memory (Cats song)|Memory]]”, Italian version | music8 = from ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'' | length8 = 5:05 | title9 = [[Everything's Alright (Jesus Christ Superstar song)|Everything's Alright]] | music9 = from ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'' | length9 = 4:31 | title10 = The Last Man in My Life | music10 = from ''[[Tell Me on a Sunday]]/[[Song and Dance]]'' | length10 = 3:09 | title11 = [[Pie Jesu]] | note11 = feat. {{Infobox television | show_name = T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle | image = TITinyTFH.jpg | genre = [[Reality television|Reality]] | creator = {{Plainlist| * Brian Sher * [[Cris Abrego]] * Stella Bulochnikov }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[T.I.]] * [[Tameka Cottle|Tameka "Tiny" Cottle-Harris]] * Zonnique Pullins * Messiah Harris * Domani Harris * Deyjah Harris * King Harris * Major Harris * Heiress Harris }} | theme_music_composer = Joël Angelo Margolis | opentheme = "Time Machine" | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 6 | num_episodes = 100 | list_episodes = List of T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle episodes | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Ben Samek * Brian Sher * Christian Sarabia * Cris Abrego * Jill Holmes * Kristen Kelly * Rabih Gholam * Stella Bulochnikov * Susan Levison * Kristen Kelly }} | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]])
[[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | runtime = 20–23 minutes | company = [[51 Minds Entertainment]]
Category 5 Entertainment | network = [[VH1]] | first_aired = {{start date|2011|12|5}} | last_aired = {{end date|2017|5|29}} | related = {{unbulleted list|''[[T.I.'s Road to Redemption]]''|''Tiny & Shekinah's Weave Trip''|''T.I. & Tiny: Friends & Family Hustle''}} | website = http://www.vh1.com/shows/ti_and_tiny_the_family_hustle/ }} '''''T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle''''' is an American [[reality television]] series that aired on [[VH1]] and premiered on December 5, 2011.{{cite web|title=VH1 Takes an In-Depth Look Into Grammy-Award Winning Rapper T.I.'s Family Life in "T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle"|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/11/09/vh1-takes-an-in-depth-look-into-grammy-award-winning-rapper-tis-family-life-in-ti-and-tiny-the-family-hustle-288201/20111109vh101/|publisher=[[The Futon Critic]]|accessdate=January 19, 2013}} The series has been concluded on May 29, 2017. ==Premise== The series chronicles the life of hip-hop artist [[T.I.]], his wife [[Tameka Cottle|Tameka "Tiny" Cottle-Harris]], and their six children.{{cite web|title=VH1 Follows Multi-Platinum Rapper T.I. in New Series Scheduled to Premiere Monday, December 5th at 10PM ET/PT|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/08/31/vh1-follows-multi-platinum-rapper-ti-in-new-series-scheduled-to-premiere-monday-december-5th-at-10pm-et-pt-99403/20110831vh101/|publisher=The Futon Critic|accessdate=January 19, 2013}} The first season follows the family after T.I.'s 12-month prison sentence.{{cite web|title=VH1 Heads Back to Screen With Returning Fan Favorites 'TI & Tiny', 'Basketball Wives' & New Series 'Ev & Ocho'|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/08/03/vh1-heads-back-to-screen-with-returning-fan-favorites-ti-tiny-basketball-wives-new-series-ev-ocho/143857/|publisher=zap2it|accessdate=January 19, 2013}} The third season encompasses T.I. as he promotes his album, ''[[Trouble Man: Heavy is the Head]]'' and his role in [[Identity Thief]]. Tiny is spending her time managing her girl group [[OMG Girlz]], starting another girl group, and holding down the family home.{{cite web|title=VH1 Adds 3 New Shows To Its Slate + Reups "T.I. and Tiny: The Family Hustle" For An Additional Season|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2013/02/21/vh1-adds-3-new-shows-to-its-slate-plus-reups-ti-and-tiny-the-family-hustle-for-an-additional-season-196301/20130221vh101/|publisher=the Futon Critic}}{{cite web|title=VH1 Debuts Another Hit Series With "T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle"|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/12/06/vh1-debuts-another-hit-series-with-%E2%80%9Ct-i-tiny-the-family-hustle%E2%80%9D/112923/|publisher=zap2it|accessdate=January 19, 2013|author=Bill Gorman|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116194130/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/12/06/vh1-debuts-another-hit-series-with-%E2%80%9Ct-i-tiny-the-family-hustle%E2%80%9D/112923/|archivedate=January 16, 2013|df=}} The fourth season picks up after T.I. completed his ''America's Most Wanted Tour'' and acting on ''[[House of Lies]]''.{{cite press release|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2014/03/17/vh1-remixes-monday-nights-with-new-and-returning-shows-on-march-31-242114/20140317vh101/|title=VH1 Remixes Monday Nights with New and Returning Shows on March 31|publisher=VH1|work=The Futon Critic|date=March 17, 2014|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} He returned to the family home in [[Atlanta]]. Tiny is working on achieving her [[General Educational Development|G.E.D.]] and making sure OMG Girlz stays constant. The couple's oldest daughter, Niq Niq, is graduating from high school. Domani is working with [[Russell Simmons]], Messiah continues to learn about fashion, and Deyjah gets a boyfriend. ==Episodes== {{main|List of T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle episodes}} {{:List of T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle episodes}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.vh1.com/shows/ti_and_tiny_the_family_hustle/}} * {{IMDb title|2128212}} {{VH1 original programming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:T.I. and Tiny: The Family Hustle}} [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:2011 American television series debuts]] [[Category:African-American reality television series]] [[Category:American reality television series]] [[Category:Television shows filmed in Atlanta]] [[Category:Television series based on singers and musicians]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:VH1 television series]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox album | name = The Blueprint 3 | type = studio | artist = [[Jay-Z]] | cover = Jay-Z - The Blueprint 3.jpg | alt = | released = September 8, 2009 | recorded = July 2008 – August 2009 | venue = | studio = {{collapsible list|title={{nobold|Various}}|ubl=true|Roc the Mic <small>([[New York City]])</small>|Avex Recording Studio <small>([[Honolulu]])</small>|Kingdom Studios <small>([[Perth]])</small>|The Holy Chataeu <small>(Perth)</small>|Baseline Studios <small>(New York City)</small>|[[Westlake Recording Studios]] <small>([[Los Angeles]])</small>|[[Oven Studios]] <small>(New York City)</small>|KMA Studios <small>(New York City)</small>|Lava Studios <small>([[Cleveland]])</small>|[[Record Plant]] <small>(Los Angeles)</small>|South Beach Studios <small>([[Miami]])</small>|Midnight Blue Studios <small>(Miami)</small>}} | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = 60:44 | label = {{hlist|[[Roc Nation]]|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Jay-Z|Shawn Carter]] <small>([[Executive producer#Music|exec.]])</small>|[[Kanye West]] <small>(also exec.)</small>|[[No I.D.]]|[[Al Shux|Shux]]|Janet Sewell-Ulepic|Angela Hunte|[[Lee Major|The Inkredibles]]|[[Swizz Beatz]]|[[Timbaland]]|[[J-Roc]]|Kenoe|[[Jeff Bhasker]]|[[The Neptunes]]}} | prev_title = [[American Gangster (album)|American Gangster]] | prev_year = 2007 | next_title = [[Jay-Z: The Hits Collection, Volume One]] | next_year = 2010 | misc = {{Singles | name = The Blueprint 3 | type = studio | single1 = [[D.O.A. (Death of Auto-Tune)]] | single1date = June 5, 2009 | single2 = [[Run This Town]] | single2date = July 24, 2009 | single3 = [[Empire State of Mind]] | single3date = October 20, 2009 | single4 = [[On to the Next One]] | single4date = December 15, 2009 | single5 = [[Young Forever (Jay-Z song)|Young Forever]] | single5date = May 11, 2010 | single6 = [[A Star Is Born (Jay-Z song)|A Star Is Born]] | single6date = June 25, 2010 }} }} '''''The Blueprint 3''''' is the eleventh [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Jay-Z]], released September 8, 2009, on [[Roc Nation]], through distribution from [[Atlantic Records]]. It is the third ''Blueprint'' album, preceded by ''[[The Blueprint]]'' (2001) and ''[[The Blueprint 2: The Gift & The Curse|The Blueprint<sup>2</sup>: The Gift & The Curse]]'' (2002). Production for the album took place during 2008 to 2009 at several recording studios and was handled by [[Kanye West]], [[No I.D.]], [[The Neptunes]], [[Jeff Bhasker]], Al Shux, [[Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], The Inkredibles, [[Swizz Beatz]], and [[Timbaland]]. This is the third ''Blueprint'' album in the ''Blueprint'' trilogy, as well as the first Jay-Z album since ''[[Vol. 3... Life and Times of S. Carter]]'' (1999) to not feature production from [[Just Blaze]].
The album debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, selling 476,000 copies in its first week. It became Jay-Z's eleventh US number-one album, breaking the record he had previously shared with [[Elvis Presley]], and produced five singles that achieved chart success. Upon its release, ''The Blueprint 3'' received generally positive reviews from music critics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1265290/jay-z-and-the-beatles-dominate-album-charts |title=Jay-Z And The Beatles Dominate Album Charts |publisher=Billboard |accessdate=February 2, 2014}}</ref>
==Background== The earliest hype over ''The Blueprint 3'' came when [[DJ Clue]] released in January 2008 a [[mixtape]] song called "Ain't I", produced by [[Timbaland]]. In the intro, Clue says, "Off that ''Blueprint 3'' baby!" However, a spokesperson for Jay-Z said that it was an old, unreleased song and that the recording of ''The Blueprint 3'' had not yet started.<ref>{{cite news | title = New Jay-Z Song Leaks -- Is Blueprint 3 In The Works? | last = Reid| first = Shaheem | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1580691/20080131/jay_z.jhtml| date = January 30, 2008| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> On July 20, Timbaland, a frequent contributor to previous Jay-Z albums, told [[MTV News]] that he would be producing the whole album.<ref>{{cite news | title = Timbaland On Producing Jay-Z's Next LP: 'It'll Be A Monster'| last = Reid| first = Shaheem | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1590927/20080715/timbaland.jhtml| date = July 16, 2008| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> But in an interview with the ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, Jay-Z called the statement "premature".<ref name = "Rolling Stone Interview">{{cite news | title = Jay-Z Teaming with Kanye West on Next Album | last = Van Dril| first = E. | author-link =| publisher = TheCelebrityCafe| url = http://thecelebritycafe.com/features/18543.html | date = September 1, 2008| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> In July 2009, Jay-Z confirmed ''The Blueprint 3'' as the album's title during an interview with radio station [[Shade 45]].<ref name = "GITD"/>
By November 2008, he had finished the album but with lengthy negotiations with Def Jam, he went on to reworking it.<ref name = "Billboard">{{cite news | title = Jay-Z: He's A Business, Man | last = Concepcion| first =Mariel | author-link =| publisher = ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''| url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268021/jay-z-hes-a-business-man| date = July 20, 2009| accessdate = July 21, 2009}}</ref> In January 2009, Jay-Z confirmed continued production of the album and admitted the leak of several songs.<ref>{{cite news | title = Jay-Z Taking His Time With Blueprint 3 To Make It 'Beyond And Above' | last = Rodriguez| first = Jayson |last2 = Calloway|first2 = Sway J. | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1603222/20090121/story.jhtmljay_z.jhtml| date = January 22, 2009| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Jay-Z Explains Blueprint 3 Delays: 'I'll Be Axl Rose Out Here!' | last = Reid| first = Shaheem| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1605288/20090218/jay_z.jhtml?rsspartner=rssBloglines| date = February 18, 2009| accessdate = July 18, 2009}}</ref> In a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine interview, Jay-Z confirmed "What We Talkin' About", the album's intro, "Thank You", and "Already Home" as song names and collaborations with [[Australian]] dance group [[Empire of the Sun (band)|Empire of the Sun]], rappers [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]] and [[Kid Cudi]] and singer [[Rihanna]].<ref name = "Billboard"/> He also mentioned in an interview with [[DJ Semtex]] that his favorite song on the album is "Empire State of Mind".<ref name="Semtex">[http://nahright.com/news/2009/07/24/audio-jay-z-interview-w-dj-semtex/ Jay-Z Interview w/ DJ Semtex]. Nah Right. Retrieved on July 25, 2009.</ref> The official track list for ''Blueprint 3'' was revealed on August 18, confirming the guest appearances from [[Kanye West]], [[Rihanna]], [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Kid Cudi]], [[Young Jeezy]], [[J. Cole]], [[Alicia Keys]], and more.<ref name="Blueprint 3 Tracklist">{{cite web | author=Dombal, Ryan | title=Jay-Z's Blueprint 3: The Tracklist | url=http://pitchfork.com/news/36262-jay-zs-iblueprint-3i-the-tracklist/ | work=[[Pitchfork (website)|''Pitchfork'']] | publisher=Pitchfork Media Inc | date=August 19, 2009 | accessdate=August 19, 2008}}</ref>)
==Artwork== The cover consists of a large amount of all-white instruments and recording tools stacked in a corner, with three red lines across the image. Rather than simply using photoshop, the album's design team carefully stacked all the equipment in a corner then used a projector to create the bars. They then painted red onto the equipment where the projection of the bars was, and replaced the projector with a camera to achieve the correct perspective for the image. ''Blueprint 3'' would be Jay-Z's first album cover that did not feature his face on it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/art-design/2013/09/best-rap-album-covers/the-blueprint-3 |title=50. Jay Z, The Blueprint 3 — The 50 Best Rap Album Covers of the Past Five Years |publisher=Complex |date=September 24, 2013 |accessdate=February 2, 2014}}</ref>
==Recording== Most of the album's recording sessions took place in [[Hawaii]] at Avex Honolulu Studio,<ref name="liner"/> in an effort to avoid leakage. West's protégé [[Mr Hudson]] explained to ''[[The Times]]'' that he "won't get bothered there" compared to a major city such as [[New York City|New York]] or [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="timesonline1">{{cite news | title = Mr Hudson Goes 'Supernova' with Kanye| last = Crerar| first = Simon | author-link =| publisher = Times Online| url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6660915.ece| date = July 8, 2009| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> Sessions for the album took place during 2008 to 2009 at Avex Honolulu Studio and several other recording studios, including Germano Studios, Oven Studios, and Roc The Mic in [[New York City]], Kingdom Studios and Lava Studios in [[Cleveland]], Midnight Blue Studios and South Beach Studios in [[Miami]], The Holy Chateau in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth, Australia]], and Westlake Studio in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="liner">''The Blueprint 3'' liner notes [[Roc Nation]] (2009)</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cduniverse.com/productinfo.asp?pid=7987186|title=Jay-Z The Blueprint 3 CD|publisher=CD Universe|accessdate=November 25, 2009}}</ref>
Jay-Z told ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' his method of selecting producers: "If Timbaland makes ten great tracks then he produces the album, if Kanye West makes ten great tracks then he produces the album; if he makes three, I'll take three. I let the music dictate the direction."<ref name = "Rolling Stone Interview"/> However, the final track listing reveals, that West produced the majority of tracks on the album, and three done by Timbaland. West confirmed two songs, "A Star Is Born" and "Young Forever", during an appearance on ''The Wake Up Show'' in February 2009.<ref>{{cite news | title = Kanye West Says 'Best Hip-Hop Beats Of All Time' Will Be On Jay-Z's The Blueprint 3 | last = Reid| first = Shaheem | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1605128/20090213/west_kanye.jhtml?rsspartner=unknown| date = February 13, 2009| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> Mr Hudson, who is the featured artist on the latter, described it as a flip on the [[Alphaville (band)|Alphaville]] [[Forever Young (Alphaville song)|record of a similar name]].<ref name = "West Hudson MTV">{{cite news | title = Mr Hudson On Working With Jay-Z: 'I'm Pinching Myself' | last = Roberts| first = Steven | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1611532/20090515/mister_hudson.jhtml| date = May 18, 2009| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref> During a joint interview with Hudson, West confirmed that the pop artist would be featured on three songs.<ref name = "West Hudson MTV"/> [[Pharrell]] stated that he emailed "So Ambitious" to Jay-Z the day he was mastering the album. He loved the track so much that he put off the mastering.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rodriguez|first=Jayson|title=Jay-Z's 'So Ambitious' Is 'Ferocious', Pharrell Williams Says|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1621726/pharrell-williams-calls-jay-z-collabo-ferocious.jhtml|publisher=MTV|accessdate=June 14, 2012|author2=Kash, Tim |date=September 16, 2009}}</ref>
==Release and promotion== The album was released September 8, 2009 on [[Roc Nation]] in the United States.<ref name="8sept">Caulfield, Keith. (September 4, 2009). [http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/e3i418c5bc24c7b68c5c254ac761738d488 Jay-Z's 'Blueprint 3' Release Date Moved To Sept. 8]. Billboard.biz. Retrieved 2009-09-05.</ref><ref name = "Release Labels">{{cite news | title = Jay-Z Confirms Roc Nation Deals With Sony, Atlantic | last = Concepcion| first = Mariel | author-link =| publisher = ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''| url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268241/jay-z-confirms-roc-nation-deals-with-sony-atlantic| date = June 30, 2009| accessdate =July 17, 2009}}</ref> It was also released digitally on September 11, 2009 in the US, and its United Kingdom and international release followed on September 14 that same year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bluesandsoul.com/feature/441/jay_z_is_back|title=A B&S Classic Interview – Pete Lewis speaks to Jay-Z|date=August 20, 2009|accessdate=September 7, 2009|first=Pete|last=Lewis|publisher=[[Blues & Soul]]}}</ref> Prior to its official release, the album [[Internet leak|leaked]] in its entirety on August 31, 2009.<ref>Langhorne, Cyrus. [http://www.sohh.com/2009/08/jay-zs_blueprint_3_leaks.html Jay-Z's 'Blueprint 3' Leaks Online Early, 'I May Be the Most Bootlegged Artist in History']. SOHH.com. Retrieved on September 11, 2009.</ref> When asked about the leak, Jay-Z stated "It's a preview. I'm excited for people to hear the album. I'm very proud of the work I've done, so enjoy it".<ref>Reid, Shaheem. Rodriguez, Jayson. [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1620482/20090831/jay_z.jhtml Jay-Z Looks at Blueprint 3 Leak As 'A Preview']. [[MTV]]. Retrieved on September 11, 2009.</ref>
The album's first single "[[D.O.A. (Death of Auto-Tune)]]" was premiered on June 5, 2009 via New York radio station [[WQHT|Hot 97]].<ref name = "Hot 97 Premiere">{{cite web |last=Schwartz |first=Barry |title=Jay-Z Premieres New Song, 'D.O.A.': 'Death Of Auto-Tune'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1613390/20090606/jay_z.jhtml|work=MTV |date=June 6, 2009 |accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> On June 7, 2009 Jay-Z made a guest appearance at Hot 97's [[Summer Jam]] concert, and performed D.O.A. live on stage, for the first time. On May 20, 2009, Jay-Z confirmed that he bought out the remainder of his contract from Def Jam Records in order to start his contract with Live Nation, as ''The Blueprint 3'' was set to be released under Roc Nation and distributed by Atlantic Records.<ref name = "Release Labels"/> In August 2008, Jay-Z performed the [[Kanye West]]–produced song "[[Jockin' Jay-Z]]" during the latter's [[Glow in the Dark Tour]].<ref name = "GITD">{{cite news | title = Jay-Z Announces Blueprint 3, Premieres New Kanye West-Produced Track At Kanye's NYC Show | last = Reid| first = Shaheem | author-link =| publisher = MTV| url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1592311/20080807/jay_z.jhtml| date = September 7, 2008| accessdate = July 17, 2009}}</ref>
==Critical reception== {{Album ratings | ADM = 6.3/10<ref>{{cite web|title=The Blueprint 3 by Jay-Z review|url=http://www.anydecentmusic.com/review/924/Jay-Z-The-Blueprint-3.aspx|website=www.anydecentmusic.com|accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref> | MC = 65/100<ref name="Metacritic"/> | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref name="Bush"/> | rev2 = ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' | rev2Score = B+<ref name="Greenblatt"/> | rev3 = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | rev3Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name="Petridis"/> | rev4 = ''[[The Independent]]'' | rev4Score = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref name="Gill">{{cite journal|last=Gill|first=Andy|date=September 18, 2009|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-jayz-the-blueprint-3-atlantic-1789649.html|title=Album: Jay-Z, The Blueprint 3 (Atlantic)|journal=[[The Independent]]|location=London|accessdate=October 19, 2012}}</ref> | rev5 = ''[[MSN Music]]'' | rev5Score = A–<ref name="Christgau"/> | rev6 = ''[[NME]]'' | rev6Score = 8/10<ref name="Cashmore"/> | rev7 = [[Pitchfork (website)|''Pitchfork'']] | rev7Score = 4.5/10<ref name="Cohen"/> | rev8 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev8Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name="Rosen"/> | rev9 = ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' | rev9Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}<ref name="McBee"/> | rev10 = ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' | rev10Score = {{Rating|2|5}}<ref name="SundayTimes">{{cite news|url=https://acs.thetimes.co.uk/?gotoUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thetimes.co.uk%2Ftto%2Farts%2Fmusic%2Falbumreviews%2F|title=Review: The Blueprint 3|newspaper=[[The Sunday Times]]|location=London|date=September 2009|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} {{subscription required}}</ref> }} ''The Blueprint 3'' received generally positive reviews from [[music journalism|music critics]]. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Standard score|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 65, based on 22 reviews.<ref name="Metacritic">[http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/jayz/blueprint3 ''The Blueprint 3'' (2009): Reviews]. [[Metacritic]]. Retrieved on September 11, 2009.</ref> In his review for [[MSN Music]], [[Robert Christgau]] called the album "fairly superb" and gave it an A- rating,<ref name="Christgau">Christgau, Robert. "[http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?name=Jay-Z Consumer Guide: ''The Blueprint 3'']". [[MSN Music]]: October 2009. Archived from [http://music.msn.com/music/consumerguide/2009/?photoidx=36 the original] on October 2, 2009.</ref> indicating "the kind of garden-variety good record that is the great luxury of musical micromarketing and overproduction".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/bk-cg90/grades-90s.php |title=CG 90s: Key to Icons |last=Christgau |first=Robert |publisher=[[Robert Christgau]] |date=October 15, 2000 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> [[AllMusic]] writer John Bush compared the album to its predecessors, describing it as "somewhere between the two, closer to the vitality and energy of the original but not without the crossover bids and guest features of the latter (albeit much better this time)".<ref name="Bush">Bush, John. [{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1633820/review|pure_url=yes}} Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. [[AllMusic]]. Retrieved on September 6, 2009.</ref> Leah Greenblatt of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' commented that the album succeeds at its goal of "reaching maximum commercial blast radius while maintaining its street bona fides".<ref name="Greenblatt">Greenblatt, Leah. [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20301975,00.html Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. Retrieved on September 5, 2009.</ref>
''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the album four out of five stars and complimented its modern sound.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|title=Jay Z – The Blueprint 3, review |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/cdreviews/6157253/Jay-Z---The-Blueprint-3-review.html |website=Telegraph.co.uk |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121223143356/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/cdreviews/6157253/Jay-Z-The-Blueprint-3-review.html |archivedate=December 23, 2012 |language=en |date=September 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave it a B+ rating and stated, "Jay-Z sounds liberated by his legacy rather than weighed down by expectations".<ref name="Rabin">Rabin, Nathan. [http://www.avclub.com/articles/jayz-the-blueprint-3,32780/ Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[The A.V. Club]]''. Retrieved on September 11, 2009.</ref> Despite noting inconsistency in Jay-Z's rapping, Jon Caramanica of ''[[The New York Times]]'' complimented the album's varied musical elements and called it "an unexpected blend of maturity and youth".<ref name="Caramanica">Caramanica, Jon (September 16, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/17/arts/music/17jayz.html Music - Jay-Z Confronts the Anxiety of Being Influential]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved on February 22, 2011.</ref> Pete Cashmore of ''[[NME]]'' commented that it "delivers because of hefty beats and quality rapsmanship, nothing else. And, ultimately, that'll do just fine".<ref name="Cashmore">Cashmore, Pete. [http://www.nme.com/reviews/jay-z/10806 Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[NME]]''. Retrieved on September 14, 2009.</ref> Kiilian Fox of ''[[The Observer]]'' commented that Jay-Z is "maturing into a responsible elder statesman".<ref name="Fox">Fox, Killian. [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/sep/13/jay-z-blueprint-3-review Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[The Observer]]''. Retrieved on September 19, 2009.</ref> Zach Baron of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' viewed that "much of ''Blueprint 3'' is about the weird, meta-rap work of redefining what it is to be a boss" and stated "Jay-Z's midlife crisis is over. Which doesn't make ''The Blueprint 3'' a classic. But we'll take it. For now".<ref name="Baron">Baron, Zach. [http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-09-08/music/jay-z-s-midlife-crisis-is-over/ Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[The Village Voice]]''. Retrieved on October 7, 2009.</ref>
In a mixed review, ''[[Slant Magazine]]''{{'}}s William McBee found ''The Blueprint 3'' "predictable", "complacent", and "a hip-hop feast, for sure, filled to the brim with elite production and elite rapping, but it lacks the hungriness, the spirit, and the craziness that marks a classic album".<ref name="McBee">{{cite web|last1=McBee |first1=William |title=Jay-Z The Blueprint 3 |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/music_review.asp?ID=1841 |website=www.slantmagazine.com |accessdate=June 26, 2017 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130104220742/http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/jay-z-the-blueprint-3/1828 |archivedate=January 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s Jody Rosen called it "a catchy, pop-friendly record", but viewed that it lacks the "electric charge" of Jay-Z's previous albums and that he is "stuck for a subject [...] But he says it well".<ref name="Rosen">{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/jayz2/albums/album/29893976/review/30083900/the_blueprint_3 |title=Review: ''The Blueprint 3'' |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |author=Rosen, Jody |date= |accessdate=September 14, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923031512/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/jayz2/albums/album/29893976/review/30083900/the_blueprint_3 |archivedate=September 23, 2009}}</ref> [[Alexis Petridis]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote that it "peters out in a mass of indistinct tracks" following its first four songs.<ref name="Petridis">[[Alexis Petridis|Petridis, Alexis]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/sep/10/jay-z-blueprint-3 Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved on September 11, 2009.</ref> ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' criticized the music's "insistent straining for a crossover, pop-coloured sheen", writing that it "mires much of the album in insipidness, coating stale braggadocio (without, mostly, any compensating humour)."<ref name="SundayTimes"/> [[Pitchfork (website)|''Pitchfork'']]{{'}}s Ian Cohen commented that it is "so certainly Jay-Z's weakest solo album, you'll be tempted to wonder if ''Kingdom Come'' was somehow underrated".<ref name="Cohen">{{cite web|last1=Cohen|first1=Ian|title=JAY-Z: The Blueprint 3 Album Review|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13445-the-blueprint-3/|website=pitchfork.com|accessdate=June 25, 2017|language=en}}</ref> [[Greg Kot]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' gave the album two-and-a-half out of four stars and viewed Jay-Z's celebrity and older age as somewhat of a flaw, stating:
{{quote|It's tough for hip-hop stars to age well. Once they become celebrities living in mansions and starring in family movies, street cred is usually the first thing to go. Just ask [[Ice Cube]]. Longevity just wasn't built into the hip-hop lifestyle, with its premium on youthful swagger, street tales and fast turnover [...] {{'}}''The Blueprint 3''{{'}} aims to show everyone he still has wicked skills on the mic. It does, even as it illustrates that sometimes he coasts on his celebrity [...] The message: Don't mess with ol' Gray-Z.<ref name="Kot">Kot, Greg. [http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/09/entertainment/et-jayz9 Review: ''The Blueprint 3'']. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Retrieved on September 8, 2009.</ref>|}}
''The Blueprint 3'' was ranked the best album of the year by ''Billboard'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/266376/billboard-critics-top-10-albums-of-2009 |title=Billboard Critics' Top 10 Albums of 2009 |publisher=Billboard.com |date=December 16, 2009 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> and seventh best album of the year by MTV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1628330/20091215/paramore.jhtml |title=The Best Albums Of 2009, In Bigger Than The Sound - Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=MTV |date=December 16, 2009 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> ''Rolling Stone'' named it the fourth best album of 2009 in its year-end list.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/31421097/the_25_best_albums_of_2009/7 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091221060750/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/31421097/the_25_best_albums_of_2009/7 |date=December 21, 2009 }}</ref>
==Commercial performance== The album debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart with first-week sales of 476,000 copies.<ref name="Caulfield"/> It serves as the third-highest first-week sales of 2009.<ref name="Caulfield">Caulfield, Keith. L.A. Herrera, Monica. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267309/jay-z-still-reigns-on-billboard-200-muse-and-kid-cudi-bow-high Jay-Z Still Reigns On Billboard 200, Muse And Kid Cudi Bow High]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on September 28, 2009.</ref> It became Jay-Z's eleventh US number-one album, breaking the record he had previously shared with [[Elvis Presley]].<ref name="Elvis">Access Hollywood. [http://omg.yahoo.com/news/jay-z-beats-elvis-for-no-1-albums-record/28019 Jay-Z Beats Elvis For No. 1 Albums Record']. [[MTV]]. Retrieved on September 16, 2009.</ref> In its second week, it remained at number 1, selling another 301,000 units, before dropping to second in its third week. After four weeks sales totaled 1,104,000 units. In the album's fifth week it sold 75,000 copies bringing the total to 1,178,000 it is Jay-Z's 11th solo album to go Platinum.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paine |first=Jake |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.9964/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-10-11-2009 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 10/11/2009 |publisher=HipHopDX |date=October 14, 2009 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> The album in its fifth week is also number 5 on the Billboard 200 albums chart. In its sixth week the album rose up 2 spots to number 3 on the ''Billboard'' 200, despite selling 65,000 copies, 10,000 less than its previous week. 53,000 copies were sold in the US in its seventh week, putting it at number 4 on the charts. In week eight the album sold 51,000 copies. In the next week album sold 48,000 units.<ref name="pg">{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/41885/week-ending-oct-18-2009-taylor-swifts-minor-miracle/ |title=Week Ending Oct. 18, 2009: Taylor Swift's Minor Miracle |publisher=Yahoo! Music |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitsdailydouble.com/sales/salescht.cgi |title=Building Album Sales Chart |publisher=HITS Daily Double |accessdate=December 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915012320/http://www.hitsdailydouble.com/sales/salescht.cgi |archivedate=September 15, 2014 }}</ref> In next three weeks album sold over 100,000 copies and, as of May 2010, its sales in the U.S. stand at 1,748,000 units.<ref name="pg"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/53748/week-ending-may-23-2010-direct-from-1972-the-rolling-stones/;_ylt=Ao8BB_laDbJgRzs_9X2SCLAPwiUv |title=Week Ending May 23, 2010: Direct From 1972, The Rolling Stones - Chart Watch |publisher=Yahoo! Music |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> It is Jay-Z's first album to have 3 Hot 100 Top 10 Hits.
The album was the 9th best selling album of 2009 in the U.S., selling over 1.52 million copies in 4 months,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/960801/taylor-swift-edges-susan-boyle-for-2009s-top-selling-album |title=Taylor Swift Edges Susan Boyle For 2009's Top-Selling Album |publisher=Billboard.com |date=September 14, 2009 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> the album is now at over 1.86 million sold and still in the Top 30.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jacobs |first=Allen |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.10520/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-1-24-2010 |title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 1/24/2010 |publisher=HipHopDX |date=January 27, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref> ''The Blueprint 3'' was the second highest selling hip-hop album of 2009 domestically. It was the 5th Highest selling Rap Album of 2010 according to Billboard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2010/the-billboard-200?begin=41&order=position |title=Music Albums, Top 200 Albums & Music Album Charts |publisher=Billboard.com |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}</ref>
On the week ending July 29, 2012, ''The Blueprint 3'' re-entered the ''Billboard'' 200 at 28. It has sold 1,933,000 copies in the US to date.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grein |first=Paul |url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-july-29-2012-albums-dog-days-145238401.html |title=Week Ending July 29, 2012. Albums: Dog Days Of Summer | Chart Watch (NEW) - Yahoo! Music |publisher=Music.yahoo.com |date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref> The album sold over 3 million records worldwide.

'''Notes''' *<sup>{{note|a|[a]}}</sup> signifies a co-producer. *<sup>{{note|b|[b]}}</sup> signifies an additional producer. * "A Star is Born" features additional vocals by [[The World Famous Tony Williams|Tony Williams]]. * "Venus vs. Mars" features additional vocals by [[Cassie Ventura|Cassie]] & [[Beyoncé]]. * "Reminder" features additional vocals by K. Briscoe.
'''Sample credits''' * "What We Talkin' About" contains a sample of "Spirit" written and performed by Frédéric Mercier. * "Thank You" contains excerpts from "Ele E Ela" as performed by Marcos Valle. * "D.O.A. (Death of Auto-Tune)" contains elements of "[[Na Na Hey Hey Kiss Him Goodbye]]" performed by [[Steam (band)|Steam]] and also contains a sample of "In the Space", written and performed by [[Janko Nilović]] & Dave Sucky * "Run This Town" contains a sample of "Someday In Athens" by Alatas Athanasios. * "Empire State of Mind" contains samples from "Love On a Two Way Street" performed by the Moment. * "On to the Next One contains samples from "[[D.A.N.C.E.]]" performed by Justice. * "A Star Is Born" contains samples from "Touch Me" performed by the Mother Freedom Band. * "Already Home" contains a sample of "Mad Mad Ivy", written by H. Mudie and performed by Gladstone Anderson and the Mudies All-Stars. * "Young Forever" contains a sample of "[[Forever Young (Alphaville song)|Forever Young]]" by [[Alphaville (band)|Alphaville]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{unreliable sources|imdb=yes|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = The Magician of Lublin | image = Magician of Lublin.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = VHS cover | director = [[Menahem Golan]] | producers = {{Plainlist| * Menahem Golan * [[Yoram Globus]] * Harry N. Blum }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Menahem Golan * [[Sheldon Patinkin]] * Irving S. White }} | based on = {{based on|''[[The Magician of Lublin (novel)|The Magician of Lublin]]''|[[Isaac Bashevis Singer]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Alan Arkin]] * [[Louise Fletcher]] * [[Shelley Winters]] }} | music = {{Plainlist| * Dov Seltzer * [[Maurice Jarre]] }} | cinematography = [[David Gurfinkel]] | editing = Dov Hoenig | studio = [[The Cannon Group#1979–1985: Golan Globus era|Golan-Globus Productions]] | distributor = [[The Cannon Group|Cannon Films]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|1979|10||[[Chicago International Film Festival|Chicago]]}} | runtime = 114 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 113:50--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/magician-lublin-1970-1 | title=''The Magician of Lublin'' (X) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=19 November 1979 | accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> | country = {{Plainlist| * Israel * West Germany }} | language = {{Plainlist| * English * German }} | budget = $6 million }} '''''The Magician of Lublin''''' is a 1979 [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] co-written and directed by [[Menahem Golan]] based on ''[[The Magician of Lublin (novel)|The Magician of Lublin]]'' by [[Isaac Bashevis Singer]]. The film's title song was performed by [[Kate Bush]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faqs.org/faqs/music/kate-bush-faq/ |title=FAQ: rec.music.gaffa – Love-Hounds – Kate Bush |publisher=Faqs.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-12}}</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079504/soundtrack Soundtrack at imdb.com]</ref>
==Plot== Yasha Mazur ([[Alan Arkin]]) is a turn-of-the-20th-century Jewish stage magician, womaniser, conman, and mystic. His great ambition is to figure out how to fly – an ambition he eventually achieves but not as a magic trick. He tours the western reaches of the old Russian Empire.
Yasha is married to Esther ([[Linda Bernstein]]), but he is rarely home in Lublin to see her and they have not been able to have any children. On the road, however, there are plenty of women to keep Yasha company. Among many others, there is the zaftig Zeftel [[Valerie Perrine]] and the Polish Catholic assistant, Magda [[Maia Danziger]], who tours and performs with him. Magda's brother is Bolek ([[Zachi Noy]]), who is incompetent; and their mother is Elzbieta ([[Shelley Winters]]), who is desperate. Magda herself, it transpires, is mentally unstable.
But the great loves of Yasha's life, and the great ambition of his love, are the aristocratic but poor widow, Emilia ([[Louise Fletcher]]), whom he would marry; and her daughter, Halina ([[Lisa Whelchel]]), whom he adores as if she were his own. But Halina is ill and needs medical care, that Emilia knows Yasha will never be able to provide; so she must keep herself free to marry someone who ''can'' pay for the medical treatment her daughter needs.
But Yasha's big break looms. In addition to demonstrating a Houdini-style escape from a tank of water while shackled, Yasha convinces his manager/impresario, Wolsky ([[Lou Jacobi]]), that he can fly. So Wolsky arranges for a booking at the prestigious Alhambra theatre in [[Warsaw]]. Yasha will at last make it big!
But then Zeftel arrives unexpectedly and innocently announces she is emigrating to America – to Buenos Aires – where a man has promised her work. But Yasha knows that Buenos Aires is in Argentina, and that man who is going to take her there is a pimp who is selling her into sexual slavery. What else can Yasha do, but perform a special show of magic and card tricks for the pimp and give him money, to save Zeftel.
Thus he misses his big break – and discovers the next morning that Zeftel had lied to him, after he attempts to burglarise the home of Count Zaruski to steal the money Emilia needs to take Halina to Italy for her cure, and so that Emilia will marry him instead of the Count. His attempt at burglary fails because he has a vision of blood and death that distracts him. He manages to escape, using his cape as wings to glide him safely to the ground. But he is emotionally fragile, knowing that he has lost Emila and Halina, as well as his career.
But real horror awaits. He makes it back to his rooms and discovers that Magda did not go to the theatre the night before. She stayed at home, dressed her face in a clown makeup, chopped her hair with a razor, and then hanged herself.
Now fully broken, Yasha returns home to Esther. His mystic vision of death having come true, he encloses himself in a brick hut with only a window, through which to receive food and communicate with people as a holy man, dispensing wisdom and blessings. Wolsky arrives, having read in the Warsaw papers about the holy man of Lublin who lives in a grave. He has brought Emilia with him, who asks Yasha's forgiveness and asks him to pray for her. She is now the Countess Zaruski, and Halina is at least in a sanitorium in Italy receiving treatment.
Another visitor from away has also come. She is a widow, heavily veiled in black mourning, who has also heard of the holy man in the brick hut, who spends his days in prayer and study of the torah, comes to seek his advice what to do. She is mourning the loss of her daughter who killed herself for love of a man, and she cannot forgive the man.
Suddenly she pulls back her veil and reveals that she is Elzbieta, come with Bolek and some friends to avenge Magda's death by killing Yasha. A battering ram is brought and attacks the brick hut, again and again, until its walls collapse and the hut is opened. Elzbieta and Bolek are ready to kill the man they blame for Magda's suicide.
But Yasha is not inside the brick hut when it is open. He is nowhere to be seen but neither could he possibly have escaped. All fall back dumbfounded by an apparent miracle, and then they see a skein of geese in the sky – and one goose in particular, chasing after it.
Yasha truly ''had'' learned to fly.
==Cast== {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- " ! Actor !! Role |- | [[Alan Arkin]] || Yasha Mazur, a magician from Lublin |- | [[Linda Bernstein]] || Esther, Yasha's wife |- | [[Louise Fletcher]] || Emelia, an aristocratic but poor widow |- | [[Lisa Whelchel]] || Halina, her daughter |- | [[Elspeth March]] || Yadwiga, their servant |- | [[Valerie Perrine]] || Zeftel, one of Yasha's regular girlfriends, whose husband is in prison |- | [[Maia Danziger]] || Magda, Yasha's assistant and lover |- | [[Shelley Winters]] || Elzbieta, Magda's mother |- | [[Zachi Noy]] || Bolek, Magda's brother |- | [[Friedrich Schoenfelder]] || Count Zaruski |- | [[Shaike Ophir]] || Shmuel, a friend of Yasha at home |- | [[Lou Jacobi]] || Wolsky, theatre impresario and Yasha's manager |- | [[Warren Berlinger]] || Herman |}
==Reception== The film was a [[Box office bomb|box office]] and critical failure.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fountain |first=Clarke |url=http://allmovie.com/work/the-magician-of-lublin-30839 |title=The Magician of Lublin > Overview |publisher=AllMovie |date= |accessdate=2011-04-12}}</ref> As an example, ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]'' wrote:
{{quote|...Golan overdramatises, tips into hysteria, and substitutes a specious mysticism that is sadly literal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/72551/the-magician-of-lublin.html |title=The Magician of Lublin Review|work=Time Out London |date= |accessdate=2011-04-12}}</ref>}}
